chapter.title: Using OS Lockdown - Enterprise and Standalone Editions

listitem.para: The information in this chapter applies to both the OS Lockdown Enterprise and OS Lockdown Standalone editions.

Some images in this chapter display a product version and revision number (e.g., v5.0.0 r23952). This number might not reflect the most current product version and revision; however, this has no impact on OS Lockdown functionality.

section.title: Quick Reference Steps
section.para: Refer to the following basic steps to create your custom security policy:

listitem.para: Select an industry-standard profile, or create a new profile that is specific to your security policy, and then associate modules to the policy. Refer to for details.
Applicable to the OS Lockdown Enterprise edition only. Create a new group, add clients and assign Security and Baseline profiles to the group. Refer to for details.
Applicable to the OS Lockdown Enterprise edition only. Optional. View, modify, and/or perform actions on individual clients, regardless of their group. Refer to for details.
Applicable to the OS Lockdown Enterprise edition only. Optional. Schedule tasks. Refer to for details.

section.title: Managing Profiles
section.para: The first step in creating your custom security policy is to create a new profile (or modify an industry-standard profile). A profile enables you to manage a collection of modules and their associated parameters.
There are two types of profiles:
A Security Profile is used for Scan, Apply and Undo actions.
A Baseline Profile determines which information about the system will be collected and included in your Baseline report.

note.para: The profile functionality is the same in OS Lockdown Enterprise and OS Lockdown Standalone editions.

procedure.para: To create a new Security Profile:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Profiles > Security Profiles. The Profiles page displays ().
The industry-standard profiles are automatically loaded on this page, indicated by the Industry-Standard checkbox, as shown in .
You cannot modify or delete industry-standard profiles directly, but you can create a copy for modification. Refer to for more information.

note.para:
Click the column headers to sort the data in descending/ascending order, as indicated by the
and
icons, respectively.

step.para: Click New. The Create New Profile page displays ().
Type the name of your profile in the Name field.
The profile Name cannot exceed 50 characters.
Click Details to optionally add a description and comment about your profile ().
The text typed in the Summary field displays on the Profiles page.
The text typed in the Description and Comments fields can be used for your internal use. For example, use the Comments field as a log to further define the profile.
Click Add/Remove Modules. The Add/Remove Modules page displays ().
Select the checkbox next to the module(s) to which you want to add to your profile.
Modules are listed in alphabetical order.
To add all modules, select the Security Modules checkbox at the top of the page.

note.para: You can also search for modules by specifying customized search criteria. Refer to for details.

step.para: If the module contains parameters, click Modify next to the module to change or view the parameter ().
For example, in , the “Password Policy Length Minimum” module parameter is shown, conveying that the user’s password must be at least five characters in length.
To view a description of the module, click on the module name. The description appears in italic font below the module name ().
For example, in , the description of the “Password Policy Length Minimum” module displays “Controls the minimum length of the user password”.
Click the [more] link to display the OS Lockdown Modules Guide in your browser.
After you have selected the modules to be added to your profile, click Save Profile.
You are returned to the Profiles page (). Note that your newly created profile now displays on this page.

important.para: Some modules are dependent upon others to complete security configuration. If you select a module with dependencies, a message displays indicating the additional required module(s) for your profile. The module(s) is then automatically added to your profile.
However, if you de-select a module that contains dependencies, the dependency module(s) are not automatically removed by the system.

section.title: Searching for Modules
section.para: OS Lockdown enables you to locate modules based on search criteria defined by you.

procedure.para: To search for specific modules:

step.para: From the Add/Remove Modules page (), click Search for Modules. The Search for Modules page displays ().
In the Search Criteria section ():

listitem.para: To expand the search criteria category, click the “+” symbol, as shown in . A search field (or drop-down list) appears enabling you to enter criteria.
To minimize the search criteria category, click the “-” symbol next to the search field (or drop-down list).
To clear all search criteria, click Remove All.

row.entry: Search Criteria Option
Description
Word Search
Use this field to enter key words that appear in the module description, or the module name.
Category

Use this drop-down list to select a category under which the module falls. A category contains a collection of individual modules that are related by a common security category (such as Password Policy). In previous OS Lockdown releases, these are referred to as “Module Groups.”
Platform

Use this drop-down list to select an application platform under which the module falls.
Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) is a structured naming scheme for platforms.
The asterisk (*) is a wild card, meaning all inclusive. For example, cpe:/a:apache:http_server:* indicates all Apache HTTP servers.
Using “cpe:/o:redhat:fedora:10” as an example, the “o” stands for “operating system.”
Using “cpe:/a:apache:http_server:*” as an example, the “a” stands for “application.”
Refer to for more information on CPEs.
Compliancy
Use this drop-down list to select a specific compliancy guideline for which the module satisfies.

step.para: Select one of the following options in the Module Pool section ():

listitem.para: Select the All Modules option to include all modules.
Select the From Industry Profile option to search for modules in a specific industry-standard profile. Select the profile from the drop-down list.
Select the From Custom Profile option to search for modules that are already associated with your profile. Select the profile from the drop-down list.

step.para: Click Perform Search. The results display in the Modules that match criteria from the pool section of the page ().
For example, in , all modules and their descriptions containing the word “lock” display, achieved by typing “lock” in the Word Search criteria field ().
Select the checkbox next to the module(s) to which you want to add to your profile.
Modules are listed in alphabetical order.

note.para: If the module contains parameters, click View next to the module to view the parameters.

step.para: Click Add Selected Modules to Profile. You are returned to the Profiles page ().
Note that the selected module(s) now display on this page for your profile.
The “red box” icon () indicates that the module already exists in your profile.

figure.title: Module Already Exists in Profile - “Red Box” Icon

section.title: Importing a Security Profile
section.para: Use the Import feature to import an existing Security Profile from a previous version of OS Lockdown (i.e., 3.x.x), or an existing Security Profile from a different edition of OS Lockdown.

procedure.para: To import a Security Profile:

step.para: From the Profiles page (), click Import. The Profile to Import field displays on the top of the page ().
Click Browse next to the Profile to Import field to search for the profile ().

note.para: The profile’s file name is internal to the system. The profile name within the XML file appears on the GUI.

step.para: Click Import. The newly imported profile displays on the Profiles page.
For example, in , the imported profile, “Profile to Import” displays in the profile list.

section.title: Exporting a Security Profile
section.para: To export a Security Profile in XML format:

step.para: From the Profiles page (), click Export. The Export Profile page displays ().
Select the Profile to be exported from the drop-down list.
Click Export Profile. Depending on your browser, the profile is either downloaded or you will be prompted to save it.
Click Return to List. You are returned to the Profiles page.

procedure.para: To edit an existing Security Profile:

step.para: From the Profiles page (), click the name of the profile to be modified.
The Edit Profile page displays (), enabling you to modify the selected profile.
After you have made the changes to your profile, click Save Profile. The changes are saved and you are returned to the Profiles page ().

procedure.para: To copy a Security Profile (including industry-standard profiles):

step.para: From the Profiles page (), click Copy. The Copy Profile page displays ().
Select the Profile to be copied from the drop-down list.
Type the name of the copied profile in the Copied Profile Name field.
By default, <copied profile> (copy) displays in this field. It is recommended that you change the name of the copied profile.
Click Copy Profile. The profile is saved in /var/lib/oslockdown/profiles/ and you are returned to the Profiles page with the newly copied profile displayed on the page.

procedure.para: To delete a Security Profile:

step.para: From the Profiles page (), select the checkbox next to the profile to be deleted.
Click Delete. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to delete the profile.
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Profiles page.

section.title: Adding a Module to a Security Profile

procedure.para: To add a module to a Security Profile:

step.para: From the Profiles page (), click the name of the profile. The Edit Profile page displays ().
Click Add/Remove Modules. The Add/Remove Modules page displays ().
Select the checkbox next to the module(s) to be added to the profile.
Click Save Profile. You are returned to the Profiles page.

section.title: Removing a Module from a Security Profile

procedure.para: To remove a module from a Security Profile:

step.para: From the Profiles page (), click the name of the profile. The Edit Profile page displays ().
Click Add/Remove Modules. The Add/Remove Modules page displays ().
De-select the checkbox next to the module(s) to be removed from the profile.
Click Save Profile. You are returned to the Profiles page.

procedure.para: To create a new Baseline Profile:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Profiles > Baseline Profiles. The Baseline Profile List page displays ().
The default Baseline Profile displays on this page. This profile represents the recommended guidelines to use for your profile.

note.para: Click the column headers to sort the data in descending/ascending order, as indicated by the and icons, respectively.

step.para: Click New. The Create Baseline Profile page displays ().
Type the name of your profile in the Name field.
The profile Name cannot exceed 50 characters.
Click Details to optionally add a description and comment about your profile ().

figure.title: Create Baseline Profile Page - Details Displayed

step.para: The text typed in the Summary field displays on the Baseline Profile List page ().
The text typed in the Description and Comments fields can be used for your internal use. For example, use the Comments field as a log to further define the profile.
For each baseline content item, select Enabled or Disabled from the drop-down list, as needed for your profile ().

note.para: A Baseline Profile requires at least one enabled baseline content item.

step.para: To view a description of the baseline content item, click on the item. The description appears in italic font below the module name, as shown in .
Click Save. The Show <your baseline profile> page appears, displaying your newly created Baseline Profile ().

section.title: Importing a Baseline Profile
section.para: Use the Import feature to import an existing Baseline Profile from a previous version of OS Lockdown (e.g., 4.0.x), or an existing Baseline Profile from a different edition of OS Lockdown.

procedure.para: To import a Baseline Profile:

step.para: From the Baseline Profile List page (), click Import. The Baseline Profile to Import field displays on the top of the page ().
Click Browse next to the Baseline Profile to Import field to search for the profile ().

note.para: The profile’s file name is internal to the system. The profile name within the XML file appears on the GUI.

step.para: Click Import. The newly imported profile displays on the Baseline Profile List page.
For example, in , the imported profile, “Baseline Profile to Import,” displays in the profile list.

section.title: Exporting a Baseline Profile
section.para: To export a Baseline Profile in XML format:

step.para: From the Baseline Profile List page (), click Export. The Export Baseline Profile page displays ().
Select the Profile to be exported from the drop-down list.
Click Export Baseline Profile. Depending on your browser, the profile is either downloaded or you will be prompted to save it.
Click Return to List. You are returned to the Baseline Profile List page.

procedure.para: To edit an existing Baseline Profile:

step.para: From the Baseline Profiles List page (), click the name of the profile to be modified. The Show <your baseline profile> page appears (), enabling you to modify the selected profile.
Click Edit at the bottom of the page.
After you have made the changes to your profile, click Update. The changes are saved and you are returned to the Show <your baseline profile> page ().

procedure.para: To copy a Baseline Profile:

step.para: From the Baseline Profiles List page (), click Copy. The Copy Baseline Profile page displays ().
Select the Baseline Profile to be copied from the drop-down list.
Type the name of the copied profile in the Copied Profile Name field.
By default, <copied profile> (copy) displays in this field. It is recommended that you change the name of the copied profile.
Click Copy Baseline Profile. The profile is saved in /var/lib/oslockdown/profiles/ and you are returned to the Baseline Profiles List page with the newly copied profile displayed on the page.

procedure.para: To delete a Baseline Profile:

step.para: From the Baseline Profiles List page (), select the checkbox next to the profile to be deleted.
Click Delete. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to delete the profile.
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Baseline Profiles List page.

section.title: Comparing Profiles
section.para: Use the Compare Profiles page to view existing comparison reports between two profiles, or create new custom comparison reports between two profiles. The Profile Comparison report lists the differences between the two profiles, including parameter values and modules contained within the profile.

procedure.para: To view an existing Profile Comparison report:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Profiles > Compare Security Profiles. The Compare Profiles page displays ().
Select the View Existing Comparison option.
Select the report comparison from the Existing Comparison drop-down list.
Select the method by which the report will be displayed from the Render As drop-down list. Valid formats are:

listitem.para: HTML (hypertext markup language)
PDF (portable document format)
TXT (text file)
CSV (comma-separated values)

step.para: Click Create/View. The system generates and displays the report. A sample Profile Comparison report rendered in HTML is shown in .

procedure.para: To create a new Profile Comparison report:

step.para: From the Compare Profiles page (), select the Create New Comparison option ().

figure.title: Compare Profiles Page - Create New Comparison

step.para: Select the first profile to compare from the Profile A drop-down list.
Select the second profile to compare from the Profile B drop-down list.
Select the method by which the report will be displayed from the Render As drop-down list. Valid formats are:

listitem.para: HTML (hypertext markup language)
PDF (portable document format)
TXT (text file)
CSV (comma-separated values)

step.para: Click Create/View. The system generates and displays the report, as shown in .

section.title: Managing Groups
section.para: The second step in creating your custom security policy is to create a new group, add clients and assign Security and Baseline profiles to the group. A group enables you to manage a collection of clients.

note.para: Group functionality is not available on the OS Lockdown Standalone edition.

procedure.para: To create a new group:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select the Groups tab. The Groups page displays ().

note.para: Click the column headers to sort the data in descending/ascending order, as indicated by the and icons, respectively.

step.para: Click New. The New Group page displays ().
In the Details section, type the Name and Description of the group.
Use the Description field to capture records for auditing purposes.
Select the Security Profile to be associated with the group from the drop-down list.

important.para: The group must be associated with a Security Profile.

step.para: Select the Baseline Profile to be associated with the group from the drop-down list.

important.para: The group must be associated with a Baseline Profile.

step.para:
In the Clients section, highlight the client(s) to be associated with the group from the Unassociated Clients pick-list, and click the
button.
The selected client moves to the Associated Clients pick-list.

To unassociate the client from the group, highlight the client from the Associated Clients pick-list, and click the
button.

important.para: A client cannot be associated with more than one group.

step.para: Click Save Group. The group is saved (as indicated by the green message on the Status Bar) and you are returned to the Groups page (). Note that the newly created group displays on this page.

note.para: The actions available on a client are the same as on a group. Refer to for details.

procedure.para: To perform an action on a group:

step.para: From the Groups page (), select the checkbox next to the group for which the action will be run.
Select the security level to be applied to the action from the Logging Level drop-down list. The default Logging Level is “Notice”.
Select the action.
For example, in , a Quick Scan was requested on “Atlanta Clients” with a Logging Level of “Notice”.
Two messages display, as shown in :

listitem.para: “1 New Notification Exists” - a notification message, indicating that the system generated a notification based on this action. This message can take several seconds to appear.
“Quick Scan requested for Groups” - the status and/or results of the action, displayed as a green message on the Status Bar.

step.para: Review the notification on the Notifications tab.

note.para: Since one module in your profile/group can cause a failed Apply/Undo action (as shown in ), it is strongly recommended to run a Scan, Apply/Undo, and a Scan again.

section.title: Creating Assessment and Baseline Reports for a Group
section.para:
It is important to note that you must perform a Scan on the group to create an Assessment report, and a Baseline on the group to create a Baseline report. If these actions are not performed first, the system cannot locate the data needed to create these reports, because the data does not exist. Assessment Report CreatingGroups
Baseline Report CreatingGroups
The group reports use the data generated from the last instance of Scan/Baseline action performed.
An Assessment report provides a “report card” of the server operating system configuration.
A Baseline report captures information (i.e., system, hardware, network, files, and software packages) about your system at a given state in time.
Use the Reports > Group Assessments page to create Group Assessment reports. Refer to for instructions.

procedure.para: To edit a group:

step.para: From the Groups page (), click the name of the group to be modified. The Show <group> page displays ().
Click Edit. The Edit Group page displays ().
After you have made the changes to the group, click Update Group. A message displays indicating that the group has been updated, and you are returned to the Groups page.

procedure.para: To delete a group:

step.para: From the Groups page (), select the checkbox next to the group to be deleted.

note.para: If a group is associated with clients, it cannot be deleted.

step.para: Click Delete. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to delete the group.
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Groups page.

section.title: Working with Group Auto-Updates
section.para: OS Lockdown enables you to push version updates from the OS Lockdown Console to the attached clients in a group. The OS Lockdown Console directly requests the clients in a group to perform any updates that are required. The decision to perform an update is controlled by the client, but the OS Lockdown Console indicates what the criteria are.
You can also perform auto-updates from the Clients page. Refer to .

note.para: The auto-update feature must be configured during the installation process (refer to , ).

section.para: Note the following auto-update scenarios:

row.entry: OS Lockdown Version Installed on Client
Auto-Update Result
Earlier than v4.0.9

entry.para: Not supported. The auto-update feature is not available on OS Lockdown versions prior to v4.0.9.
A request to auto-update on the Groups page will fail. A message displays on the OS Lockdown Console indicating that auto-updates are not supported on OS Lockdown versions prior to v4.0.9.
Instead, refer to for instructions on how to manually invoke auto-updates on the client(s) in a group.

row.entry: v4.0.9 or later

entry.para: Use the steps in this section to perform auto-updates on the Groups page.

procedure.para: To perform an auto-update on a group:

step.para: From the Groups page (), select the checkbox next to the group(s) to which the update will apply.
Select one of the following options from the Auto-Update drop-down list:

listitem.para: Release Number - compares the release number offered by the OS Lockdown Console and the release number installed on the client(s) in the group. If the versions are different, an update is requested. For example, if the OS Lockdown Console’s release number is 4.0.10, and the client’s release number is 4.0.9, an update is performed.

Package Versions - compares the packages offered by the OS Lockdown Console to those installed on the client(s) in the group. If any required packages are missing, or if the actual build numbers are different for any installed packages, then an update is performed. In addition, if the OS Lockdown Console provides a required package that is not on the client(s), then an update is required. For example, the OS Lockdown Console provides r18328, and the client has r18299, an update is performed.
Force - regardless of the packages installed, an update is required and performed.

step.para: The client’s release number and package version are displayed on the Client Details page, as shown in .

figure.title: Client Details Page - Client Details Displayed

step.para: Click Auto-Update. The following message indicates that the update will be pushed to the client(s) in the group regardless of peak hour or load threshold settings ().
Click OK. Two messages display, as shown in :

listitem.para: “3 New Notifications Exists” - indicates that the system generated notifications based on the auto-update request. This message can take several seconds to appear.
“AutoUpdate requested for Groups. Refer to Notification page for status results.” - indicates the status and/or results of the auto-update, displayed as a green message on the Status Bar.

step.para: Review the notifications on the Notifications page.
On the Client Details page, click the Refresh Status button to verify that the client’s version package number matches that of the OS Lockdown Console.

section.title: Managing Clients
section.para: An optional step in creating your custom security policy is to view, modify, and/or perform actions on the client(s) (i.e., Scan, Quick Scan, Apply, Baseline). A client is any supported operating system that is managed by the OS Lockdown Console. Refer to for a list of supported operating systems.

note.para: Client functionality is not available on the OS Lockdown Standalone edition.

procedure.para: To view a client:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Clients > List Clients. The Clients page displays ().
The client(s) registered during the installation process (, ) appears on this page by default.

Click the column headers to sort the data in descending/ascending order, as indicated by the
and
icons, respectively.

section.title: Performing Actions on a Client
section.para: OS Lockdown enables you to perform the following actions on a client:

listitem.para: Abort - stops the action running on the client.
Apply - configures the client to the security configurations to comply with a selected profile.
Baseline - takes a snapshot of the server and allows for comparisons between two different servers or two baselines for the same server.

Quick Scan - scans the client to provide an assessment of which security modules pass or fail and omits those modules that are system intensive and take longer to complete, such as those containing complete system scans. Some modules that are potentially long running modules will also exit with a failing status on the first detected problem rather than locate all problems.

Scan - scans the client to provide an assessment of what security modules pass or fail, including all modules associated with the profile which is assigned to the client’s group. This scan may take several minutes to complete.
Undo - provides the ability to undo an Apply action to revert the client configuration to the last known configuration that the OS Lockdown application knows for that server.

note.para: Since one module in your profile/group can cause a failed Apply/Undo action (as shown in ), it is strongly recommended to run a Scan, Apply/Undo, and a Scan again.

section.para: You can also assign a severity level (e.g., Logging Level) to each action. The Logging Level filters the type, and consequently the volume of results generated from the action. The results are generated and viewed in the Client Application logs (refer to for more information).
Severity levels include:

listitem.para: Emergency - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered an emergency condition indicating that the action failed.
Alert - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered an alert condition indicating that some level of the action failed.
Critical - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered a critical condition indicating that some level of the action failed.
Error - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered one or more error conditions.
Warning - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered one or more warning conditions.
Notice - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered one or more normal, but significant conditions.
Informational - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered messages that contain system information.
Debug - while performing the action, OS Lockdown encountered messages used to debug the system.

section.para: Logging Levels appear in order of verbosity, where the “Debug” level generates the greatest amount of data, while “Emergency” generates the least. For example, if you perform an action with a “Debug” logging level, the system returns all messages from “Debug” through “Emergency” levels.
Once the system completes an action, the results display in a notification. Refer to for more information.

procedure.para: To perform an action on a client:

step.para: From the Clients page (), select the checkbox next to the client for which the action will be run.
Select the security level to be applied to the action from the Logging Level drop-down list.
The default Logging Level is “Notice”.
Select the action. In , a Quick Scan was requested on the “Client 2” client with a Logging Level of “Notice”.
Two messages display, as shown in :

listitem.para: “1 New Notification Exists” - a notification message, indicating that the system generated a notification based on this action. This message can take several seconds to appear.
“Quick Scan requested for Clients” - the status and/or results of the action, displayed as a green message on the Status Bar.

step.para: Review the notification on the Notifications tab.

section.title: Creating Assessment and Baseline Reports for a Client
section.para: It is important to note that you must perform a Scan on the client to create an Assessment report, and a Baseline on the client to create a Baseline report. If these actions are not performed first, the system cannot locate the data needed to create these reports, because the data does not exist.
The reports created from the Clients page use the data generated from the last instance of Scan/Baseline action performed.
An Assessment report provides a “report card” of the server operating system configuration.
A Baseline report captures information (i.e., system, hardware, network, files, and software packages) about your system at a given state in time.

note.para: Refer to for details on reports.

procedure.para: To create the latest Assessment or Baseline report on a client:

step.para: From the Client page (), click the name of the client.
The Client Details page displays ().

In the Reports section, click Assessment or Baseline, as applicable. The Assessment Report or Baseline Report page displays, enabling you to select the report criteria. Refer to and respectively, for more information.

note.para: Depending on your client configuration and connectivity, generating these reports may take several minutes.

procedure.para: To edit a client:

step.para: From the Clients page (), click the name of the client to be modified.
The Client Details page displays ().
Click Edit. The Edit Client page displays.
After you have made the changes to the client, click Update. The system displays a message indicating that the client has been updated.

note.para: You can only edit the information in the <client name> Configuration section of this page; all other information is read-only.

procedure.para: To delete a client:

step.para: From the Clients page (), select the checkbox next to the client to be deleted.
Click Delete. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to delete the client.
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Clients page.

section.title: Working with Client Auto-Registration Requests
section.para: The Auto-Registration Request page enables you to view, accept or deny a client registration request that was generated during the client registration process (refer to , ).

procedure.para: To view and accept an auto-registration request:

step.para: After the client installation and configuration process is complete, a notification message displays on the Dashboard indicating that a client request exists.
Click on the notification message, or select Clients > Auto-Registration Requests to view the request. The Auto-Registration Requests page displays.
Click the link in the Received column. A details page containing the client registration information displays.
Optionally assign the client to a group by selecting it from the Group drop-down list. This allows you to add the accepted client into the group at the same time that the client is accepted.
Click Allow or Deny. A pop-up message displays asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to allow the client registration. The newly registered client appears in the Clients page.

section.title: Working with Client Auto-Updates
section.para: OS Lockdown enables you to push version updates from the OS Lockdown Console to the attached clients. The OS Lockdown Console directly requests the client to perform any updates that are required. The decision to perform an update is controlled by the client, but the OS Lockdown Console indicates the criteria.
You can also perform auto-updates from the Groups page. Refer to .

note.para: The auto-update feature must be configured during the installation process (refer to , ).

Auto-Update Result

A request to auto-update on the Groups page will fail. A message displays on the OS Lockdown Console indicating that auto-updates are not supported on OS Lockdown versions prior to v4.0.9.
Instead, refer to for instructions on how to manually invoke auto-updates on the client(s) in a group.

row.entry: v4.0.9 or later

entry.para: Use the steps in this section to perform auto-updates on the Groups page.

procedure.para: To perform an auto-update on a client(s):

step.para: From the Clients page (), select the checkbox next to the client(s) for which the update will apply.
Select one of the following options from the Auto-Update drop-down list:

listitem.para: Release Number - compares the release number offered by the OS Lockdown Console and the release number installed on the client. If the versions are different, an update is requested. For example, if the OS Lockdown Console’s release number is 4.0.10, and the client’s release number is 4.0.9, an update is performed.

Package Versions - compares the packages offered by the OS Lockdown Console to those installed on the client. If any required packages are missing, or if the actual build numbers are different for any installed packages, then an update is performed. In addition, if the OS Lockdown Console provides a required package that is not on the client(s), then an update is required. For example, the OS Lockdown Console provides r18328, and the client has r18299, an update is performed.
Force - regardless of the packages installed, an update is required and performed.

“AutoUpdate requested for Clients” - indicates the status and/or results of the auto-update, displayed as a green message on the Status Bar.

section.title: Console Audit Log
section.para: The Console Audit Log is used to track user actions performed on the OS Lockdown Console.

The log files are stored in /var/lib/oslockdown/logs/ and rotate when the log size exceeds 10 MB. The system maintains up to 50 log files before the oldest is erased. For example oslockdown-audit.log, oslockdown-audit.log.1, and oslockdown-audit.log.2 represent three audit logs, where oslockdown-audit.log is the current log file and oslockdown-audit.log.2 is the oldest.

procedure.para: To view the Console Audit Log:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Logging > Console Audit Log. The Console Audit Log page displays ().
By default, the last actions performed by the user display in the body of the page.
Optional. Click the Filters arrow to reveal log filtering options ().
To expand the filter criteria category (e.g., User), click the “+” symbol. A search field (or drop-down list) appears enabling you to enter criteria.
To minimize the filter criteria category, click the “-” symbol next to the search field (or drop-down list).

figure.title: Console Audit Log Page - Filters Displayed

step.para: Specify the filter criteria.
By default, the search criteria string is joined by “ANDs”.

listitem.para: User - the user responsible for the action.
Group - the group on which the action(s) occurred.
Profile - the profile on which the action(s) occurred.
Action - any action performed by the system (i.e., Scan, Apply, Baseline, etc.).
Client - the client on which the action(s) occurred.
Word - any search words to be used as a filter. If left blank, it can be used as a wildcard.
Display type drop-down list:
The Filter Out Unmatching Lines option exclusively displays lines that match your search criteria.
The Highlight Matching Lines option displays all lines in the log, and highlights the lines that match your filter criteria (refer to for an example).

section.title: Scheduling
section.para: Use the scheduling functionality to schedule a time and date for an action (Scan, Apply, Baseline) to occur on your network (client). When you schedule a task, it is executed on the client even if the OS Lockdown Console is down or is unable to reach the client for a period of time. The client sends a notification to the OS Lockdown Console once the scheduled task is complete.

note.para: The scheduler functionality is not available on the OS Lockdown Standalone edition.

procedure.para: To schedule a new task:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Scheduler. The Scheduler page displays ().
Click New. The Create Scheduled Task page displays ().
Select the Group and Logging Level for which the task applies from the drop-down lists.
Specify the frequency in which the task will execute on the client (daily, weekly, or monthly), and the time of day in HH:MM format (where HH is the hour, and MM is minutes in military time).
Select the action from the drop-down list (Scan, Apply, or Baseline).
Click the “+” symbol to schedule more than one action for the task.
Click the “-” symbol to delete the action.
Click Save. The scheduled task is saved and you are returned to the Scheduler page ().
Note that the newly created task displays on this page and on the Show <group> page ().

section.title: Synchronizing a Scheduled Task
section.para: When you synchronize a scheduled task, the OS Lockdown Console pushes the data to the clients to ensure consistency.
For example, synchronize a scheduled task if:

listitem.para: A client was off-line at the time the task was scheduled.
A client was “down” (e.g., unplugged network cord).
New clients were added to the group associated with the scheduled task update.
The client IP address changed.

section.para: Synchronizing the scheduled tasks ensures that all clients are updated with the most current task information.

procedure.para: To synchronize a scheduled task:

step.para: From the Scheduler page (), select the checkbox next to the scheduled task to be synchronized.
Click Synchronize. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to synchronize the selected task(s).
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Scheduler page.
A pop-up displays if errors occur.

important.para: It is important to remember to synchronize the modified scheduled task with the clients. Refer to for instructions.

procedure.para: To edit a scheduled task:

step.para: From the Scheduler page (), click the name of the scheduled task to be edited. The Edit Scheduled Task page displays (), enabling you to modify the scheduled task.
After you have made the changes to the scheduled task, click Update. The scheduled task is saved and you are returned to the Scheduler page ().

procedure.para: To delete a scheduled task:

step.para: From the Scheduler page (), select the checkbox next to the scheduled task to be deleted.
Click Delete. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to delete the scheduled task.
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Scheduler page.

section.title: Administration
section.para: Use the Administration pages to manage system user accounts, import/export (back up) system data, and to set password aging and complexity criteria.

section.title: Managing Users
section.para: The Manage Users page enables you to create additional system users, assign roles to users, and edit and delete user accounts.

procedure.para: To create a new user account:

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Administration > Manage Users. The Manage Users page displays ().
The default Username (“admin”) and Role (“Administrator”) display on this page and cannot be modified.

note.para:
Click the column headers to sort the data in descending/ascending order, as indicated by the
and
icons, respectively.

step.para: Click New. The Create User page displays ().
Type the name of the user in the Username field.
The Username is case-sensitive.
Select the user’s Role from the drop-down list.
Click the Display Actions Table arrow to view the actions allowable for each role ():

listitem.para: Administrator
Management
Security Officer
User

step.para: Type the user’s Password.
The Password is case-sensitive and must be at least six characters and contain both a capital letter and a number.
Type the user’s password again in the Re-enter Password field.
Click Save. The user account information is saved and you are returned to the Manage Users page (). Note that the newly created user now displays on this page.

procedure.para: To edit a user account:

step.para: From the Manage Users page (), click the name of the user account for which you want to edit. The Edit <user> page displays, enabling you to modify the user account ().
After you have made the changes to the user account, click Update. The user account information is saved and you are returned to the Manage Users page.

procedure.para: To delete a user:

step.para: From the Manage Users page (), select the checkbox next to the user for which you want to delete.
Click Delete. A pop-up message displays, asking you to confirm your decision.
Click OK to delete the user account.
Or, click Cancel to cancel the action and return to the Manage Users page.

section.title: Managing the Database
section.para: The Manage Database page enables you to upload, import, and export (back up) system data in XML format. The database files are stored in /var/lib/oslockdown/console/. System data should be backed up according to your company-specific policy.

If you are currently running the v3.x.x OS Lockdown Console, use the /usr/share/oslockdown/tools/sb-convert-db2xml.sh script to convert your existing database into an XML file which can be uploaded into the v4.x.x OS Lockdown Console.

note.para: Database management is not available on the OS Lockdown Standalone edition.

procedure.para: To export (back up) the database (i.e., profiles, clients, groups, and tasks):

step.para: From the Menu Bar (), select Administration > Manage Database. The Manage Database page displays ().
Click Export Database Snapshot in the Export database to XML snapshot section.
The most recent database instance is exported to /var/lib/oslockdown/console/dbexport/ in XML format, with a timestamp appended to the filename.

procedure.para: To import a snapshot:

step.para: From the Manage Database page (), select the snapshot to import from the drop-down list in the Import local XML snapshot into database section. The snapshots that were exported (backed up) are available to import.
Click Import Snapshot. The results of the import (success/failure) display on the Import Results page.
Retrieve the snapshot from /var/lib/oslockdown/console/.

procedure.para: To upload a snapshot:

step.para: From the Manage Database page (), click Browse to locate the XML file for which you want to upload in the Upload XML snapshot into database section.
Click Upload Snapshot. The results of the upload (success/failure) display on the Import Results page.
Retrieve the snapshot from /var/lib/oslockdown/console/.

section.title: Managing Account Preferences

section.title: Managing Upstream Notification Preferences
section.para: The OS Lockdown Administrative Console uses the standard syslog system logging facility to send notifications of certain activities and events. These messages are formatted to be compliant with the Common Event Format (CEF), and the messages may be sent via syslog to a centralized log receiver. It is the administrator’s responsibility to configure the appropriate receiver of these messages. contains a breakdown of the basic messages and key values that are being used.

The Manage Upstream Notification Preferences page () allows you to enable/disable notifications as well as schedule when certain checks will be performed. When any changes are made, the Update Upstream Notification Preferences button at the bottom of the page must be used to persist any changes.

The Upstream Notification Preferences section is used to configure the destination of all OS Lockdown related upstream notifications, and a basic trigger level that can be used to only send messages above a certain level, or disable all upstream logging entirely.

section.para: Upstream notification triggers are events that should trigger an upstream notification when they occur.

row.entry: Perform a comparison report between the last action and the immediately preceding same action and determine if there is a “new” finding. At this moment, this is restricted to scheduled scans, and will only report issues where a module has moved from a “pass” state to a “fail” state, or any occurrence of a module in an “error” state.
